"Purple Palace" refers to his office in the Purple Palace, where he oversees the thirty-five bureaus of destiny and promotes the ranks of true immortals. As Yang, he presides over the East, where the nine *qi* of Lesser Yang generate and transform the myriad things. "August Emperor" denotes his station in the East, the honored sovereign of all heavens, the lord who shepherds the multitude of sages and the king who engenders all beings.

chunks.original_text: 东岳三月二十八日生 泰山者，乃群山之祖，五岳之宗，天地之神，神灵之府也。 在兖州奉符县，今太安州是也。 以梁父山为储副。 东方朔《神异经》曰：昔盘古氏五世之苗裔日赫天氏，赫天氏日胥勃氏，胥勃氏日玄英氏，玄英氏子日金输王，金轮王弟曰少海氏，少海氏妻曰弥轮仙女也。 弥轮仙女夜梦吞二日，觉而有娠生二子，长曰金蝉氏，次日金虹氏。 金虹氏者，即东岳帝君也，金蝉氏即东华帝君也。 金虹氏有功在长白山中，至伏羲氏封为古岁，为太华真人掌天仙六籍，遂以岁为姓，讳崇。 其古岁者，乃五岳之前无上天尊所都之地，今之奉高是也。 其后乃水一天尊之女也。 至神农朝赐天符都官，号名府君。 至汉明帝封太山元帅，掌人世居民贵贱高下之分，禄枓长短之事，十八地狱六案簿籍，七十五司生死之期。 圣帝自尧、舜、禹、汤、周、秦、汉、魏之世，只有天都府君之较，按《唐会要》曰：武后垂拱二年七月初一日封东岳为神岳天中王，武后万岁通天元年四月初一日尊为天齐君。 玄宗开元十三年加封天齐王。 宋真宗大中祥符元年十月十五日诏封东岳天齐仁圣王，至祥符四年五月日尊为帝号：东岳天齐仁圣帝。 淑明皇后，圣朝加封大生二字，余封如故。 帝五子，宣灵侯，惠灵侯，和惠夫人，至圣炳灵王，永泰夫人，居仁尽鉴尊师，佑灵侯，淑惠夫人。 帝一女，玉女大仙。 即岱岳太平顶玉女娘娘是也。 南岳 南岳衡山，衡州衡山县是也，以霍山为储副。 东方朔《神异经》云：姓崇，讳覃。 南岳主於世界星辰分野之地，兼麟甲水族龙鱼之事。 大中祥符四年五月二十五日追尊帝号：司天昭圣帝，景明皇后。 圣朝加封大化二字，余封如故。 西岳 西岳华山，在华州华阴县是也，以太白山为储副。 东方朔《神异经》云：神姓善，讳里。 西岳者主管世界金银铜铁五金之属，陶铸坑冶，兼羽毛飞乌之事。 大中祥符四年五月日追尊帝号：金天顺圣帝，肃明皇后。 圣朝加封大利二字，余封如故。 北岳 北岳恒山，在定州曲阳县是也。 以略峒山为储副。 东方朔《神异经》云：神姓晨，讳锷。 北岳者主於世界江河淮济，兼虎豹走兽之类，蛇虺昆虫等属。 大中祥符四年五月日追尊帝号：安天玄圣帝。 静明皇后。 圣朝加封大贞二字，余封如故。 中岳 中岳嵩山，在西京河南府登封县是也。 以少室山为储副。 东方朔《神异经》云：神姓惮，讳善。 中岳者主於世界地泽川谷沟渠山林树木之属。 大中祥符四年五月日追尊帝号：中天崇圣帝。 正明皇后。 圣朝加封大宁二字，余封如故。 四渎神 江渎神，即楚屈原大夫也。 唐始封二字公，宋加四字公。 本朝加封四字王，号广源顺济王。 河渎神，即汉陈平也。 唐始封二字公，宋加四字公。 本朝加封四字王，号灵源弘济王。 淮渎神，即唐裴度也。 唐始封二字公，宋加四字公。 本朝加封四字王，号长源候济王。 济渎神，即楚作大夫也。 唐始封一字公，宋加四字公。 本朝加封四字王，号清源汉济王。 五方之神 武王伐纣都洛邑，天大雨雪，甲子朔五神车骑止王门之外，欲谒武王。 王曰：诸神各有名乎？ 师尚父曰：南海神名祝融，北海神名玄冥，东海神名勾芒，西海神名募收，河泊名冯修。
chunks.translated_text:
The Eastern Marchmount is born on the twenty-eighth day of the third month. Mount Tai is the ancestor of all mountains, the patriarch of the Five Marchmounts, the spirit of Heaven and Earth, and the abode of divine numina. It is located in Fengfu County of Yanzhou, now known as Tai’an Prefecture, with Liangfu Mountain as its deputy.

According to *The Classic of Divine Marvels* by Dongfang Shuo: In ancient times, among the descendants of Pangu, the fifth generation was He Tian Shi, followed by Xu Bo Shi, then Xuan Ying Shi. Xuan Ying Shi’s son was King Jin Shu, whose younger brother was Shao Hai Shi. Shao Hai Shi’s wife was the Immortal Lady Mi Lun. One night, the Immortal Lady Mi Lun dreamed of swallowing two suns and awoke pregnant, giving birth to two sons. The elder was named Jin Chan Shi, and the younger was Jin Hong Shi. Jin Hong Shi became the Lord of the Eastern Marchmount, while Jin Chan Shi became the Lord of the Eastern Florescence.

Jin Hong Shi rendered meritorious service on Changbai Mountain. During the reign of Fuxi, he was enfeoffed as Gu Sui, the True Person of Mount Taihua, and entrusted with the registers of the six celestial immortals. Thus, he took Sui as his surname, with the personal name Chong. Gu Sui was the capital of the Supreme Heavenly Worthy before the Five Marchmounts, now known as Fenghao. His mother was the daughter of the Heavenly Worthy of Primordial Water.

During the reign of Shennong, he was granted the celestial tally as the Prefect of the Capital and titled Lord. In the Han dynasty, Emperor Ming enfeoffed him as Marshal of Mount Tai, overseeing the distinctions of nobility and humility among the world’s inhabitants, the duration of their official salaries, the registers of the eighteen hells and six bureaus, and the life-and-death cycles of the seventy-five departments.

Since the eras of Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, the Zhou, Qin, Han, and Wei dynasties, the Divine Lord has been known only as the Prefect of Tiandu. According to *The Tang Compendium*: In the second year of Chuigong during Empress Wu’s reign, on the first day of the seventh month, the Eastern Marchmount was enfeoffed as the Divine Marchmount King of the Central Heaven. In the first year of Wansui Tongtian, on the first day of the fourth month, he was honored as the Heavenly Equal Lord. In the thirteenth year of Kaiyuan during Emperor Xuanzong’s reign, he was further enfeoffed as the Heavenly Equal King. In the first year of Dazhong Xiangfu during Emperor Zhenzong’s reign, on the fifteenth day of the tenth month, an edict enfeoffed him as the Heavenly Equal Benevolent and Sagely King. By the fourth year of Xiangfu, on a day in the fifth month, he was elevated to the imperial title: Heavenly Equal Benevolent and Sagely Emperor of the Eastern Marchmount. The Virtuous and Illustrious Empress was later honored with the addition of "Great Life" to her title, while the rest of her enfeoffment remained unchanged.

The Emperor has five sons: the Proclaiming Numen Marquis, the Kindly Numen Marquis, the Harmonious Kindness Lady, the Illustrious Numen King of Utmost Sagacity, and the Eternal Peace Lady. They reside as the Revered Master of Benevolence and Exhaustive Insight, the Assisting Numen Marquis, and the Virtuous Kindness Lady. The Emperor has one daughter, the Great Immortal Jade Maiden, known as the Jade Maiden Lady of the Taiping Peak of Mount Tai.

The Southern Marchmount: Mount Heng of the Southern Marchmount is located in Hengshan County of Hengzhou, with Mount Huo as its deputy. *The Classic of Divine Marvels* by Dongfang Shuo states that the deity’s surname is Chong, with the personal name Tan. The Southern Marchmount governs the stellar correspondences of the world and oversees the affairs of scaled creatures, aquatic beings, dragons, and fish.

In the fourth year of Dazhong Xiangfu, on the twenty-fifth day of the fifth month, he was posthumously honored with the imperial title: Illuminating Sagely Emperor of Celestial Governance, with the Radiant and Illustrious Empress. The sagely dynasty later added the characters "Great Transformation" to his title, while the rest of his enfeoffment remained unchanged.

The Western Marchmount: Mount Hua of the Western Marchmount is located in Huayin County of Huazhou, with Mount Taibai as its deputy. *The Classic of Divine Marvels* by Dongfang Shuo states that the deity’s surname is Shan, with the personal name Li. The Western Marchmount governs the world’s gold, silver, copper, iron, and other metals, as well as foundries, smelting, and the affairs of feathered birds.

In the fourth year of Dazhong Xiangfu, on a day in the fifth month, he was posthumously honored with the imperial title: Compliant and Sagely Emperor of the Golden Heaven, with the Solemn and Illustrious Empress. The sagely dynasty later added the characters "Great Profit" to his title, while the rest of his enfeoffment remained unchanged.

The Northern Marchmount: Mount Heng of the Northern Marchmount is located in Quyang County of Dingzhou, with Mount Luodong as its deputy. *The Classic of Divine Marvels* by Dongfang Shuo states that the deity’s surname is Chen, with the personal name E. The Northern Marchmount governs the world’s rivers—Jiang, Huai, and Ji—and oversees tigers, leopards, and other beasts, as well as snakes, vipers, and insects.

In the fourth year of Dazhong Xiangfu, on a day in the fifth month, he was posthumously honored with the imperial title: Mysterious and Sagely Emperor of Peaceful Heaven, with the Serene and Illustrious Empress. The sagely dynasty later added the characters "Great Integrity" to his title, while the rest of his enfeoffment remained unchanged.

The Central Marchmount: Mount Song of the Central Marchmount is located in Dengfeng County of the Western Capital’s Henan Prefecture, with Mount Shaoshi as its deputy. *The Classic of Divine Marvels* by Dongfang Shuo states that the deity’s surname is Dan, with the personal name Shan. The Central Marchmount governs the world’s marshes, valleys, ravines, ditches, mountains, forests, and trees.

In the fourth year of Dazhong Xiangfu, on a day in the fifth month, he was posthumously honored with the imperial title: Revered and Sagely Emperor of the Central Heaven, with the Upright and Illustrious Empress. The sagely dynasty later added the characters "Great Peace" to his title, while the rest of his enfeoffment remained unchanged.

The Gods of the Four Waterways: The God of the Jiang Waterway is Qu Yuan, the Grand Master of Chu. The Tang dynasty initially enfeoffed him as a two-character duke, and the Song dynasty added two more characters to his title. The present dynasty further enfeoffed him as a four-character king, titled the King of Vast Source and Compliant Salvation.

The God of the He Waterway is Chen Ping of the Han dynasty. The Tang dynasty initially enfeoffed him as a two-character duke, and the Song dynasty added two more characters to his title. The present dynasty further enfeoffed him as a four-character king, titled the King of Numinous Source and Vast Salvation.

The God of the Huai Waterway is Pei Du of the Tang dynasty. The Tang dynasty initially enfeoffed him as a two-character duke, and the Song dynasty added two more characters to his title. The present dynasty further enfeoffed him as a four-character king, titled the King of Long Source and Candidate Salvation.

The God of the Ji Waterway is the Grand Master of Chu. The Tang dynasty initially enfeoffed him as a one-character duke, and the Song dynasty added three more characters to his title. The present dynasty further enfeoffed him as a four-character king, titled the King of Pure Source and Han Salvation.

The Gods of the Five Directions: When King Wu of Zhou conquered Zhou and established his capital in Luoyi, Heaven sent a great snowstorm. On the first day of the jiazi month, the five divine chariots and cavalry halted outside the king’s gate, seeking an audience. The king asked, “Do the gods each have names?” Marshal Jiang Shang replied, “The God of the Southern Sea is named Zhu Rong, the God of the Northern Sea is named Xuan Ming, the God of the Eastern Sea is named Gou Mang, the God of the Western Sea is named Ru Shou, and the God of the Rivers and Lakes is named Feng Xiu.”

chunks.original_text: 使谒者以名召之，神皆警而见武王。 王曰：何以教之？ 神曰：天伐殷立周，谨来受命，各奉其使。 武王曰：子岁时无废礼焉。 按传共工氏子日龙主社为后土神，少昊子日重主木为勾芒神，颛顼子黎喜火为祝融神，少昊第二子该主金为募收神，少昊第三子熙王水为玄冥神。 太乙 天神也，按《汉书》：刘向校书天禄阁，有老人着黄衣植青华而进见，向在暗中，遂出杖端火照向读书。 向问其姓名，答曰：我太乙之精。 肩吾 按《山海经》：昆仑之丘是实惟帝之下都，神陆吾司之，其神人面虎身虎爪九尾，司天之九部及帝之囿时。 庄子所谓肩吾得之以处太山是也。 烛阴 海外锺山之神名曰烛阴，即烛龙也。 其神视为书瞑，为夜吹，为冬呼，为夏不饮，不食不息，气息为风，身长千里，人面蛇身，一足赤色，在无昔之国。 雷神六月二十四日生 庙在雷州之西南八里，昔乡人尝造雷鼓雷车置庙中。 有以鱼乱肉同食者，立为霆震。 旧记云：陈天建初州民，陈氏者因猎获一卵，围及尺余，拥归家。 忽一日霹雳而开，生一子，有文在手，日雷州，后养成，名文玉，乡俗呼为雷种。 后为本州刺史，殁而有灵，乡人庙祀之，阴雨则有电光吼声自庙而出。 宋元累封王爵，庙号显震，德佑中更名威化。 《国史补》：雷州春夏多雷，秋日则伏地中，其状如负，人取而食之。 又雅州瓦屋山有雷洞，投以瓦石应手电震。 电神 相传东王公与玉女投壶最而脱误不接者，天为之笑，开口流光，今之闪电是也。 风伯 飞廉是也，应助曰：飞廉神禽，能致风气，身似鹿，头似爵，有角，尾似蛇，大如豹。 雨师 商羊是也。
chunks.translated_text:
The herald was sent to summon them by name, and the gods all came forth in solemn attendance to meet King Wu. The king asked, “What instructions do you bring?” The gods replied, “Heaven has overthrown Yin and established Zhou. We come in reverence to receive our mandates, each to fulfill our appointed tasks.” King Wu said, “You shall not neglect the seasonal rites in your honor.”

According to tradition, Gonggong’s son, Ri Long, presides over the earth as the God of the Soil (Houtu). Shaohao’s son, Ri Zhong, presides over wood as the God Gou Mang. Zhuanxu’s son, Li Xi, presides over fire as the God Zhu Rong. Shaohao’s second son, Gai, presides over metal as the God Ru Shou. Shaohao’s third son, Xi Wang, presides over water as the God Xuan Ming.

Taiyi is a celestial deity. According to the *Book of Han*, when Liu Xiang was collating texts in the Tianlu Pavilion, an old man in yellow robes, holding a staff tipped with blue blossoms, appeared before him. As Liu Xiang sat in darkness, the staff’s light illuminated his reading. When asked his name, the old man replied, “I am the essence of Taiyi.”

Jianwu: According to the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*, Kunlun’s peak is the divine capital where the emperor descends. The god Lu Wu governs it—a being with a human face, tiger’s body, tiger’s claws, and nine tails, overseeing the nine celestial divisions and the emperor’s seasonal gardens. This is the same Jianwu whom Zhuangzi speaks of as dwelling on Mount Tai.

Zhuyin: The god of Zhong Mountain beyond the seas is named Zhuyin, also called the Torch Dragon. His eyes open to create daylight and close to bring night. He exhales to summon winter’s breath and inhales to cease in summer. He neither eats nor drinks nor rests, and his breath becomes wind. His body stretches a thousand *li*, with a human face, serpent’s form, one red foot, and he dwells in the land of Wuxi.

The Thunder God was born on the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month. His temple lies eight *li* southwest of Leizhou. In former times, villagers crafted thunder drums and thunder chariots, placing them in the temple. Once, a man ate fish and meat together, and instantly a thunderbolt struck him. Ancient records state: During the Tianjian era of the Chen dynasty, a man of the Chen clan, while hunting, found an egg over a *chi* in circumference and took it home. One day, it split open with a thunderclap, revealing a child with markings on his hand reading *Leizhou*. Raised to adulthood, he was named Wen Yu, and the locals called him the “Seed of Thunder.” Later, he became prefect of the region. After his death, he displayed divine power, and the villagers built a temple in his honor. Before storms, lightning and roars would issue from the temple. The Song and Yuan dynasties repeatedly enfeoffed him as a king, and his temple was named Xianzhen. During the Deyou era, it was renamed Weihua.

The *Guoshi Bu* notes: In Leizhou, thunder is frequent in spring and summer, but in autumn, it burrows into the earth, taking the form of a curled creature, which people dig up and eat. On Mount Wawu in Yazhou, there is a Thunder Grotto—when tiles or stones are thrown in, they trigger lightning in response.

The Lightning God: Legend holds that the Eastern King and the Jade Maiden were playing a game of pitch-pot. When a shot missed, Heaven laughed, its open mouth streaming light—what we now call lightning.

The Wind Earl is Feilian. Ying Shao states: Feilian is a divine bird that commands the winds. Its body resembles a deer, its head a sparrow, with horns and a serpent’s tail, and it is as large as a leopard.

The Rain Master is Shangyang.

chunks.original_text: 商羊神乌，能小，吸则淇渤可枯。 搜神记卷之一竟 ＃１『卷之一』原无，据体例补。 ＃２『黄』原为『皇』，据文义改。 ＃３『常』原为『当』，据文义改。 ＃４『木』原为『人』，据文义改。 搜神记卷之二#1 目录 玄天上帝　　北极驱邪院左判官 梓潼帝君　　吴客三真君　许真君 张天师　　　三茅真君 祠山张大帝　五圣　　　至圣炳灵王 佑圣真君　　王侍宸　　袁千里 张果老　　　西岳真人　太素真人 萨真人　　　寿春真人　负局先生 律吕神刘师 玄天上帝三月初三日生 按《混洞赤文》所载，玄帝乃元始化身，太极别体。 上三皇时下降为太始真人，中三皇时下降为太朴真人#2，下三皇时下降为太素真人。 至黄帝时下降为当上天，开皇初劫下世，紫云元年建甲午，三月甲寅庚午时符太阳之精，托胎化生序乐国王善胜夫人之腹，孕秀一十四月，则太上八十二化也。 争乐国者，乃奎娄之下海外国，上应龙变梵度天。 玄帝产母左脸，当生之时瑞云覆国异香芬然，地上变金玉瑞应之祥。 生而神灵，举措隐显，年及十岁，经典一览悉皆默会，仰观俯察靡所不通，潜心念道志气太虚，愿辅上帝普福兆民。 父王不能抑志，年十五，辞父母欲寻幽谷内炼元真，遂感玉清圣祖紫虚元君，传授无极上道。 元君告玄帝曰：子可越海东游，历於翼翰之下，有山自乾兑起迹，盘旋五万里，水出震宫，自有太极便生是山，应显定极风天太安皇崖二天。 子可入是山，择众峰之中冲高紫霄者居之。 当契太和升举之后五百岁，当龙汉二劫中，披发铣足摄离坎真精归根复位，上为三境辅臣，下作十方大圣，方得显名亿劫，与天地日月齐并，是其果满也。 告毕，元君升云而去。 玄帝乃如师语，越东海游，步至翼翰之下，果见师告之山，山水藏没，皆符师言。 乃入观览，果有七十二峰，中有一峰耸翠上凌紫霄，下有一岔当阳虚寂，於是玄帝采师之诚，目山曰太和山，峰曰紫霄峰，岔日紫霄岔，因卜居焉。 潜虚玄一，默会万真。 四十九年，大得上道，於黄帝紫云。 五十七年，岁次甲子九月初九日丙寅清晨，忽有祥云．天花自空而下，迷漫山谷，去山四方各三百里林峦震响，自作步虚仙乐之音，是时玄帝身长九尺，面如满·月，龙眉凤目，钳发美髯，颜如冰清，顶九气玉冠，身披松罗之服，跌足拱手，立於紫霄峰上。 须臾云散，有五真群仙降於玄帝之前，导从甚盛，非凡见闻。 玄帝稽首，祇奉迎拜，五真曰：予奉三清王帝诏，以子功满道备升举，今闻子之圣父圣母已在九霄矣。 玄帝跪伏恭韶，五真乃宣诏毕，可特拜太玄元一帅，领元和迁校府公事，赐九德偃月金一晨玉冠，琼华玉簪，碧瑶宝圭，素销飞一云金霞之被，紫销龙兖丹裳羽属绛彩一之裙，七宝铢衣，元光朱履，飞红云乌，一佩太玄元帅玉册，乾元宝印，南北二一斗、三台龙剑，飞云玉辖，丹举绿辇，羽一益琼轮九色之节，十绝灵膳，前踞九凤，后次八鸾，天下玉女亿乘万骑，上赴九清诏至奉行。 玄帝再拜授诏，易服讫，飞升金阙。 按《元洞玉历记》云：殷纣日造罪愆恶毒自横，遂感六大魔王，引诸鬼众伤害众生。 元始乃命玉皇上帝降诏紫薇，阳则以周武伐纣，阴以玄帝收魔。

**Hunt for the Supernatural, Scroll Two**
*Catalogue*
The Dark Celestial Thearch  Left Judging Official of the Northern Culmen Exorcism Court
The Lord Emperor of Zitong  Three Perfected Lords of Wu  Perfected Lord Xu
Heavenly Master Zhang  Three Mao Perfected Lords

Perfected Sa  Perfected of Shouchun  The Gentleman Who Carries the Kiln on His Back
Divine Master of Pitch and Timbre, Liu Shi

The Dark Celestial Thearch was born on the third day of the third month. According to the *Red Writ of the Chaotic Abyss*, the Dark Thearch is an emanation of the Primordial Beginning, a distinct embodiment of the Supreme Ultimate. During the era of the Upper Three Sovereigns, he descended as the Perfected of Great Inception; in the Middle Three Sovereigns, as the Perfected of Great Simplicity; and in the Lower Three Sovereigns, as the Perfected of Great Simplicity. By the time of the Yellow Emperor, he descended as the Sovereign of the Supreme Heaven. At the dawn of the Kaihuang kalpa, he descended into the world. In the first year of Ziyun, the jiawu year, on the jiayin day of the third month, at the gengwu hour, he aligned with the essence of the Great Yang and entered the womb of Lady Shansheng of the King of Shengle, gestating for fourteen months—this was the eighty-second transformation of the Supreme.

Shengle was a kingdom beneath the lunar lodges Kui and Lou, beyond the eastern sea, corresponding to the Dragon-Transformation Brahma-Heaven. When the Dark Thearch was born from his mother’s left cheek, at the moment of his birth, auspicious clouds enveloped the kingdom, rare fragrances filled the air, and the earth transformed into gold and jade, manifesting wondrous omens. Born with divine numinosity, his every movement was mysterious and elusive. By the age of ten, he had mastered all classics at a glance, comprehending them in silence. Gazing above and below, there was nothing he did not penetrate. He concealed his heart in the Dao, his aspirations aligned with the Great Void, and he vowed to assist the Thearch in bestowing universal blessings upon the people. His father could not restrain his resolve. At fifteen, he bid farewell to his parents to seek secluded valleys and refine his primordial authenticity. Thereupon, the Purple Void Primordial Sovereign of the Jade Purity Saintly Ancestress was moved and transmitted to him the Supreme Dao of the Limitless.

The Primordial Sovereign addressed the Dark Thearch, saying: “You should cross the eastern sea and journey beneath the wings of the Han. There is a mountain whose traces rise from Qian and Dui, coiling for fifty thousand li. Its waters flow from the Zhen Palace. This mountain arises naturally with the Supreme Ultimate, corresponding to the Wind Heaven of the Firmly Established Culmen and the Great Peace August Cliff of the Second Heaven. You should enter this mountain and dwell among its peaks, choosing the central and loftiest one, the Purple Empyrean. When the era of Supreme Harmony and ascension arrives, five hundred years later, during the two kalpas of Dragon Han, you shall bind your hair, tread barefoot, and gather the true essences of Li and Kan to return to the root and restore your position. Above, you will become a minister of the Three Realms; below, a great sage of the Ten Directions. Only then will your name be manifest for countless kalpas, equal to heaven and earth, sun and moon—this will be the fulfillment of your fruit.”

Having spoken, the Primordial Sovereign ascended upon the clouds and departed. The Dark Thearch followed his master’s instructions, crossing the Eastern Sea and journeying until he stood beneath the wings of the Han. There, he indeed saw the mountain his master had described, its waters and terrain all matching his words. He entered to survey it and found seventy-two peaks, among which one soared emerald-green, piercing the Purple Empyrean. Below it lay a ravine facing the sun, serene and empty. Thus, the Dark Thearch, honoring his master’s sincerity, named the mountain Great Harmony, the peak Purple Empyrean Peak, and the ravine Purple Empyrean Ravine. He then divined his dwelling there, concealing himself in the mysterious unity of the Void and silently communing with the myriad Perfected.

After forty-nine years, he profoundly attained the Supreme Dao. In the fifty-seventh year, on the ninth day of the ninth month of the jiazi year, at dawn on the bingyin day, suddenly auspicious clouds and celestial blossoms descended from the sky, filling the valleys. For three hundred li in every direction, the forests and peaks resounded with the spontaneous music of the immortals’ *bu xu* hymns. At that moment, the Dark Thearch stood nine feet tall, his face like the full moon, brows like dragons, eyes like phoenixes, his hair bound in a topknot, his beard fine. His countenance was as clear as ice, his head crowned with a nine-qi jade coronet, his body clad in pine-fiber robes. Barefoot and with hands clasped, he stood upon Purple Empyrean Peak.

In an instant, the clouds dispersed, and five Perfected Ones and a host of immortals descended before the Dark Thearch, their retinue magnificent beyond mortal perception. The Dark Thearch bowed deeply, reverently receiving them. The Five Perfected said: “We bear the decree of the Three Clarities and the Jade Emperor. Your merit is complete, your Dao perfected, and you are to ascend. We have heard that your sagely father and sagely mother now reside in the Nine Empyreans.” The Dark Thearch knelt and prostrated himself, receiving the edict with reverence. The Five Perfected then proclaimed the decree, appointing him as the Supreme Marshal of the Great Mystery and Unity, charged with overseeing the affairs of the Yuanhe Migration Bureau. They bestowed upon him the Nine-Virtue Crescent Moon Golden Dawn Jade Coronet, the Jade Hairpin of Qionghua, the Jasper Jade Scepter, the Cloud-Soaring Silver Robe of Golden Radiance, the Purple Cloud Dragon Robe with Cinnabar Skirt and Feathered Adornments, the Seven-Treasure Silk Garment, the Vermilion Shoes of Primordial Light, the Flying Red Cloud Crow, the Jade Tablet of the Supreme Marshal of the Great Mystery, the Qian-Yuan Treasure Seal, the Northern and Southern Dippers, the Three Terraces Dragon Sword, the Jade Rein of Flying Clouds, the Cinnabar Chariot of Green Ascension, the Nine-Colored Jade Wheel of Feathered Beneficence, the Ten Unfailing Numinous Provisions, nine phoenixes leading the way, eight simurghs following, and a hundred million jade maidens and celestial steeds. He was to ascend to the Nine Clarities and carry out the decree.”

The Dark Thearch bowed twice, received the decree, changed his attire, and ascended to the Golden Portal. According to the *Jade Calendar of the Primordial Abyss*, during the reign of King Zhou of Yin, his daily transgressions and malevolence grew ever more rampant, provoking the descent of six great demon kings who led hordes of ghosts to harm living beings. The Primordial Beginning then commanded the Jade Emperor to issue a decree to the Purple Tenuity: in the yang realm, King Wu of Zhou would overthrow Zhou; in the yin realm, the Dark Thearch would subdue the demons.

chunks.original_text: 斯时，上赐玄帝披发胱足金甲玄袍皂尽玄旗，统领丁甲下降凡世。 与六天魔王战於洞阴之·野，魔王以坎离二气化苍龟巨蛇，变现方成，玄帝神力摄於足下，锁鬼众於邓都大洞。 宇宙肃清，玄帝凯还，特赐尊号，拜玉虚师相玄天上帝，领九天采访使。 圣父曰：摩乐天君明真大帝，圣母曰：善胜太后琼真上仙。 下荫天关曰：太玄火精命阴将军赤灵尊神。 地轴曰：太玄水精育阳将军鱼灵尊神，并居天一。 北极驱邪院左判官 左判官者，唐颜真卿。 德宗命真卿问罪李希烈亲族饯於长乐坡，公醉跳踯前楹曰：吾早遇道士云陶八，八授以刀圭碧霞丹，至今不衰。 又曰：七十有厄即吉，他日待我於罗浮山，得非今日之厄乎。 公至大梁，希烈命缢杀之，葬於城南。 希烈败家，人殷柩见貌状如生遍身金色，爪甲出手背须发长数尺，归葬偃师北山。 后有商人至罗浮山。 有二道士弈棋树下，一曰何人至此？

Leading the hosts of celestial soldiers, he descended to the mortal realm. There, he battled the six demon kings of the Six Heavens in the wilds of the Cavernous Yin. The demon kings transformed the qi of Kan and Li into a colossal black turtle and a monstrous serpent, but the Dark Thearch’s divine power pressed them beneath his feet, binding the ghostly hordes within the Great Cavern of Fengdu. With the cosmos pacified, the Dark Thearch returned in triumph. chunks.original_text: 答曰：小客洛阳人。 道士笑曰：愿寄一书达吾家。 遣童子取纸笔作书，客还至北山，颜家子孙得书惊曰：先太师亲笔。 发冢开棺已空矣。 后白玉蟾云：颜真卿为北极驱邪左判官。 梓撞帝君二月初三日生 州按《清河内传》：余本昊会问人，生於周初，后七十三化为士大夫，未尝酷民虐吏，性烈而行察，同秋霜白日之不可犯。 后西晋末，降生於越之西，隽之南，两郡之问。 是时丁未年二月三日诞生，祥光罩户黄云迷野。 居处地俯近海里，人请清河叟曰：君令六十而获贵嗣，童稚时不喜嬉戏，每慕山泽，往往语言若有隐显，尽诵群书，丧避众子，自笑自乐，身体光射，居民祈梼则余嗤讪，长啸曰：土木而能衣人之衣，食人之食，享之而有应，谤之而有祸，我为人而焉无灵乎。 自后夜梦或为龙，或为王者天符，或为水符，漕自怪而不甚信为吉兆。 三农愆旱嘉禾无苏，舞雩祝神括然无验，余思曰：寐中梦治水府，今夕当验。 夜往水际，以梦中官函牒河伯，而惊魂尤恐忸怩不能，忽尔之问阴云四合风飞雷震。 一吏稽首余前曰：运判徒居。 余曰：非我也，我乃张户老之子，名亚。 绿水府得达，故字需美。 吏曰：奉命从子。 余曰：家人如何。 吏曰：先到治所。 余惶惧未庾，吏揖上一白驴而去。 倪首里闸风雨声中顿失乡地，到一山，连剑岭而撑参宫星也，若凤凰之偃，下有舌揪引余入一巨穴。 门有一石，荀吏曰：民之梼雨祝此石而有应，名日雷柱。 吾方寨衣入穴，吏又曰：君记周室为人七十三化，阴德传家而迄今否？ 余方大悟，若梦觉也。 吏曰：君在天谱得神之品，於人世界有知之者。 晋不日有中兴之兆，君可寻方而显化。 余曰：谢天使响报也。 入穴则若堕千仞之壑，近地而足不沾，若腾身虚空。 有王者之＇官中有禁卫，余入遂见家人，悉都其问。 改日作儒士往咸阳，讲姚慕之故事。 庙在剑州梓潼县九曲之北，其殿有降笔亭，中以金索悬一五色飞鸾，鸾口衔笔用金花栈数百番，常留笔下，笔墨皆具亭门，本府差官封锁甚严，以防欺伪之弊。 降等讫，其亭内有铜锺自呜，庙吏闻於本府，本府差官启钥取书以观报应，其降笔多劝人以忠孝为本。 昨逆曦僭为蜀王，具牺牲设姐豆洁集盛亲诣帝君庙设祭，甫欲行礼，黑风骤起灭烛撒香，逆曦震惧俯伏殿下，须臾开明，视祝板已碎作两片矣。 帝君奉唐玄宗追封左丞相。 僖宗加封顺济王。 宋太祖加封圣号忠烈仁武孝德圣烈王，圣后协应德惠妃，圣父显庆慈佑仁裕王，圣母昭德积庆慈淑妃，圣子嗣德王，圣子妇善助显懿夫人，圣子昌德王，圣子妇顺助惠懿夫人，圣孙绍应昭灵侯，圣孙妇淑应夫人，圣孙承应宣灵侯，圣孙妇惠应夫人。 佐神英惠忠烈翼济福安王卿报喜太尉也，左右桂禄二籍仙官。 延佑三月七日加封圣号辅元开化文昌司禄宏仁帝君。 吴客三真君 昔周厉王有三谏官，唐、葛、周也。 王好畋猎失政，三官谏曰：先王以仁义守国，以道德化民，而天下咸服，未闻禽荒也。 迭谏弗听，三官弃职南游於昊，昊王大悦。 会楚兵侵昊，王甚忧之，三官进曰：臣等致身以死事大王自有安邦之谋，大王无虑。 三官迎敌各用神策，楚降，昊王迁赏三官，拜辞奏曰：臣等客臣也，不敢受赐。

He sent a young disciple to fetch paper and brush, then wrote a letter. When the merchant returned to the northern mountains of Yanshi, the descendants of the Yan family received the letter and exclaimed in shock, “This is our late Grand Preceptor’s own hand!”

According to the *Inner Records of Qinghe*: I was originally a being of the Heavenly Assembly, born at the beginning of the Zhou dynasty. After seventy-three transformations, I became a scholar-official, never oppressing the people or abusing my authority. My nature was stern and my conduct scrutinous—unyielding as autumn frost or the noonday sun.

At the end of the Western Jin, I was reborn in the region between Yue and Jun. It was the dingwei year, the third day of the second month, when I was born. Auspicious light enveloped the household, and yellow clouds shrouded the fields. My dwelling lay near the sea. The villagers addressed me as the Old Man of Qinghe and said, “At sixty, you have at last been blessed with a noble heir.” As a child, I disliked play and yearned for mountains and marshes. My speech often seemed cryptic, yet I recited all the classics. I shunned the company of other children, laughing and rejoicing alone. My body radiated light, and when the villagers came to pray, I would scoff at them. I would cry out in a long whistle: “If mere earth and wood can clothe themselves in human garments, eat human food, and bring blessings when worshipped or misfortune when slandered—how can I, a man, lack spirit?”

Thereafter, I dreamed at night of becoming a dragon, or of receiving the celestial tally of a king, or of bearing the water tally. Though I found these dreams strange, I did not fully believe them to be auspicious omens. When the three harvests failed and drought withered the crops, the rain dances and prayers to the gods yielded no response. I thought: “In my dream, I governed the Water Palace. Tonight, it shall be proven.”

That night, I went to the water’s edge and, as in my dream, presented the river god with an official document. My soul trembled with fear, and I could not compose myself. Suddenly, dark clouds gathered, winds howled, and thunder roared. An official knelt before me and said, “The Regional Judge has arrived.”

I replied, “It is not I. I am the son of Zhang the Elder, named Ya.”

The Water Palace had received word, so they called me Xuemei.

The official said, “I am here at your command.”

I asked, “How fares my family?”

He replied, “They have already arrived at the administrative office.”

Still trembling, I bowed my head. The official gestured toward a white donkey, and we departed. In the midst of the storm, I lost all sense of my homeland. We arrived at a mountain, where the Sword Ridge soared like the stars of Shen and Can, resembling a phoenix at rest. Below, a tongue-like path led me into a vast cavern. At the entrance stood a stone. The official said, “When the people pray for rain and touch this stone, their prayers are answered. It is called the Thunder Pillar.”

As I lifted my robe to enter the cavern, the official spoke again: “Do you recall that in the Zhou dynasty, you were a man who, after seventy-three transformations, passed down hidden virtue through your family—does this continue to this day?”

Then I fully awakened, as if from a dream.

The official said, “Your name is recorded in the celestial registers as a divine being. In the human world, there are those who know of you. The Jin dynasty will soon show signs of revival. You may seek a method to manifest your transformation.”

I replied, “I thank the celestial messenger for this revelation.”

Upon entering the cavern, I felt as though I had fallen into an abyss of a thousand fathoms, yet my feet did not touch the ground—I seemed to float in midair. Within the palace of the king, guards stood at attention. I entered and saw my family, all gathered there.

On another day, I donned the robes of a scholar and traveled to Xianyang, where I lectured on the tales of Yao and Mu. The temple stands north of the Nine Bends in Zitong County, Jianzhou. Within its halls is the Pavilion of Descending Brush, where a five-colored flying simurgh is suspended by a golden chain. The simurgh’s beak holds a brush adorned with hundreds of layers of golden blossoms. The brush remains poised above the pavilion, with ink and paper always at the ready. The temple’s doors are sealed by officials appointed by the prefecture to prevent fraud.

When the brush descends, a bronze bell in the pavilion rings of its own accord. The temple officials report this to the prefecture, and the appointed officials unlock the doors to retrieve the message. The writings often exhort people to take loyalty and filial piety as their foundation.

Recently, the usurper Xi arrogated the title of King of Shu. He prepared sacrificial animals and ritual vessels, purified himself, and personally visited the temple of the Emperor to offer sacrifices. As he was about to perform the rites, a black wind suddenly rose, extinguishing the candles and scattering the incense. Xi trembled in fear and prostrated himself before the hall. When the wind subsided, he saw that the prayer tablet had split in two.

The Emperor was posthumously enfeoffed by Emperor Xuanzong of Tang as Left Chancellor. Emperor Xizong of Tang further enfeoffed him as King of Shunji. Emperor Taizu of Song bestowed upon him the sacred title *Loyal, Martial, Filial, and Virtuous Divine King*. His sacred consort was the *Virtuous and Harmonious Concubine of Cooperative Power*; his sacred father, the *Manifest, Celebrated, Benevolent, and Protective King of Abundant Kindness*; his sacred mother, the *Illustrious and Virtuous Concubine of Accumulated Blessings*; his sacred son, the *Hereditary King of Continuing Virtue*; his sacred daughter-in-law, the *Virtuous and Manifest Lady of Excellent Assistance*; his sacred second son, the *King of Flourishing Virtue*; his sacred second daughter-in-law, the *Virtuous and Harmonious Lady of Compliant Assistance*; his sacred grandson, the *Marquis of Illustrious Response to Inherited Mandate*; his sacred grandson’s wife, the *Lady of Virtuous Response*; his sacred second grandson, the *Marquis of Proclaiming Response to Mandate*; and his sacred second grandson’s wife, the *Lady of Kind Response*.

Among his assisting deities: the *King of Blessed Peace, Loyal, Martial, and Assisting Wings*, who serves as the Grand Marshal of Auspicious Tidings; the two celestial officials of the left and right registers of cinnamon and emolument.

On the seventh day of the third month of the third year of the Yanyou era, he was further enfeoffed with the sacred title *Emperor of Vast Assistance, Opener of Transformation, Controller of Emolument, and Vast Benevolence*.

The Three Perfected Lords of Wu:
In the time of King Li of Zhou, there were three remonstrating officials: Tang, Ge, and Zhou. The king was fond of hunting and neglected governance. The three officials admonished him, saying: “The former kings governed the state with benevolence and righteousness, transforming the people through virtue. Thus, the realm submitted in harmony. We have never heard of a ruler who indulged in the reckless pursuit of game.”

Their repeated remonstrances went unheeded, so the three officials resigned their posts and journeyed south to Wu. The King of Wu was greatly pleased. When the army of Chu invaded Wu, the king was deeply troubled. The three officials stepped forward and said: “We offer our lives in service to Your Majesty. We have a plan to secure the state—do not worry.”

The three officials met the enemy, each employing divine strategies. Chu surrendered, and the King of Wu wished to reward them. They declined, saying: “We are but guest ministers. We dare not accept your gifts.”

He was reburied in the northern mountains of Yanshi. Later, a merchant traveled to Mount Luofu, where he saw two Daoists playing chess beneath a tree. One asked: “Who has come here?”

chunks.original_text: 后知厉王薨，宣王立，复归周国。 宣王锡责甚厚，仍其爵位。 后救太子靖王降五方使者，及非灾横祸，宣王迁三官於东衰，抚治安慰民受其赐，商请其资所至无乏，其国大治，三官既升加封侯号。 唐宏字文明孚灵侯，七月二十一日诞。 葛雍字文度威灵侯，二月十三日诞。 周武#3字文刚浃灵侯，十月初二日诞。 宋祥符元年真宗东封岱岳，至天门忽见三仙自空而下，帝敬问之。 三仙曰：臣奉天命护卫圣驾。 帝封三仙曰：上元道化真君，中元护正真君，下元定志真君，同判岱岳冥司。 赞曰：应变之圣，道德之君。 辞周寄昊，济世救民。 周而烈极，昊封客臣。 宋遇真宗，天门显身。 帝亲问之，方得其因。 唐葛周氏，天地水神。 上奉王诏，保驾圣明。 御制妙赞，敕载姓名。 祠封太顶，号建三灵。 许真君八月初一日 许真君名逊，字敬之，汝南人也。 祖父世慕至道，真君弱冠师大洞真君昊猛传三清法。 举孝廉，拜蜀旌阳令。 以晋乱弃官，与昊君问游江左。 会王敦作乱，二君乃假符咒谒敦，欲止敦而存晋也。 一日同郭璞候敦，敦蓄怒而见，曰：孤昨梦将一木上破其天，禅帝位果十全乎？ 请先生圆之。 许曰：此梦非吉矣。 日木上破天是宋字，明公未可妄动。 又令璞筮之，曰事无成。 问寿，曰：若起事祸将不久，若住武昌寿不可测。 敦怒曰：卿寿几何？ 曰：予寿尽今日。 敦令武士执璞赴刑，二君同敦饮席问乃隐形去。 至卢江口召舟过锺陵，舟师以无人力驾红。 二君曰：但载我，我自行红。 仍戒舟师曰：汝宜坚闭户隐，若闻舟行声慎勿潜窥，於是入舟，顷刻问舟师闻舟摇撼木叶声，遂潜窥。 见二龙驾舟在紫霄峰顶。 龙知其窥，委舟而去。 二君曰：汝不信吾教，今至此，奈何。 遂令舟师舟隐此峰顶，教服灵草，授以神仙术，舟之遗迹今尚存。 真君后在豫章遇一少年，客仪修整自称慎郎，真君与之话知非人类。 既去谓门人曰：适少年即蛟蜃精，吾念江西累遭洪水为害，若不剪除恐致逃遁。 遂举道眼一观，见蜃精化一黄牛於洲壮，真君谓弟子施太玉曰：彼黄牛，我今化黑牛，仍以白巾与斗，汝讯之当以剑截彼。 俄顷二牛奔逐，大玉以剑中黄牛之左股。 因投入城西井中，黑牛亦入井，蜃精径走。 蜃精先在潭州化一聪明少年人，多珍宝，娶刺史贾玉女，常旅游江湖必多获宝货而归，至是空归，且云被盗所伤。 须臾典客报云：有道流许敬之见使君，贾出接坐。 真君曰：闻君得佳婿#4，略请见之。 慎即托疾不出。 真君厉声曰：蛟精老魅焉敢遁形。 蛟乃化本形至堂下#5，命空中神杀之。 又令将二儿来真君，以水嘤之，即成小蜃。 妻贾氏几变，父母力恳乃止。 令穿屋下丈余，地皆无水际，又令急移，俄顷官舍沉没。 为浑综迹皆宛然旨蜃。
chunks.translated_text:
Later, learning of King Li’s death and King Xuan’s ascension, they returned to the Zhou realm. King Xuan bestowed upon them rich rewards and restored their ranks. Subsequently, they rescued Crown Prince Jing by subduing the envoys of the Five Directions and averted unnatural disasters. King Xuan then stationed the three officials in Dongcui, where they governed with compassion, soothing the people and distributing their bounty. Merchants petitioned for their resources, and wherever they went, want was unknown. The state flourished, and the three officials were elevated and enfeoffed as marquises. Tang Hong, styled Wenming, was granted the title *Fuling Hou* and was born on the twenty-first day of the seventh month. Ge Yong, styled Wendu, was granted the title *Weiling Hou* and was born on the thirteenth day of the second month. Zhou Wu, styled Wengang, was granted the title *Jialing Hou* and was born on the second day of the tenth month.

In the first year of the Xiangfu era of the Song, Emperor Zhenzong performed the Feng sacrifice at Mount Tai. As he reached the Heavenly Gate, he suddenly saw three immortals descend from the sky. The emperor respectfully inquired of them. The three immortals replied: “We are commanded by Heaven to protect Your Majesty’s carriage.” The emperor then enfeoffed the three immortals as *Shangyuan Daohua Zhenjun*, *Zhongyuan Huzheng Zhenjun*, and *Xiayuan Dingzhi Zhenjun*, jointly overseeing the netherworld administration of Mount Tai.

The eulogy reads:
*Adaptive sages, lords of virtue and power,*
*They left Zhou for Wu, saving the world and its people.*
*In Zhou, their glory reached its peak; in Wu, they were honored as guest ministers.*
*In Song, they met Zhenzong, revealing themselves at the Heavenly Gate.*
*The emperor personally inquired, and thus learned their cause.*
*Tang, Ge, and Zhou—spirits of Heaven, Earth, and Water—*
*By royal decree, they guarded the sagely carriage.*
*The emperor composed a wondrous eulogy, inscribing their names.*
*At the summit’s shrine, the Three Spirits were established.*

---

**Xu Zhenjun** (born on the first day of the eighth month)
Xu Zhenjun, named Xu Xun, styled Jingzhi, was a native of Runan. His ancestors had long revered the supreme Dao. In his youth, Zhenjun studied under the Great Cavern Perfected Lord Wu Meng, receiving the teachings of the Three Clarities. He was recommended as a *xiaolian* and appointed magistrate of Jinyang in Shu. Due to the chaos of the Jin, he resigned his post and traveled east of the Yangtze with Lord Wu. When Wang Dun rebelled, the two lords presented themselves to Wang, bearing talismans and incantations, seeking to halt his rebellion and preserve the Jin.

One day, they visited Wang Dun alongside Guo Pu. Wang, harboring resentment, received them and said: “Last night, I dreamed of lifting a wooden beam that shattered the heavens. Will my usurpation of the imperial throne be entirely successful?” He asked them to interpret the dream. Xu replied: “This dream is not auspicious. The wood breaking through the heavens forms the character *song* (宋). Your Grace must not act rashly.” He then instructed Guo Pu to divine the matter, who said: “It will not succeed.” When asked about Wang’s lifespan, Guo replied: “If you rise in rebellion, disaster will come swiftly. If you remain in Wuchang, your fate will be unfathomable.” Enraged, Wang asked: “How long is *your* lifespan?” Guo answered: “My life ends today.” Wang ordered his guards to seize Guo Pu and execute him. The two lords, still at the banquet, vanished in an instant.

They reached the mouth of the Lu River and summoned a boat to cross to Zhongling. The boatman refused, saying no one was available to row. The two lords said: “Just take us aboard; we will propel the boat ourselves.” They warned the boatman: “You must firmly shut the door and hide. If you hear the sound of the boat moving, do not peek.” Once aboard, the boatman soon heard the creaking of the vessel and the rustling of leaves. Unable to resist, he stole a glance and saw two dragons pulling the boat atop Zixiao Peak. The dragons, sensing his gaze, abandoned the boat and departed. The two lords said: “You disobeyed our instructions. What is to be done now?” They then left the boatman atop the peak, teaching him to consume sacred herbs and imparting the arts of immortality. The boat’s traces remain there to this day.

Later, in Yuzhang, Zhenjun encountered a young man of refined bearing who called himself Shen Lang. Zhenjun conversed with him and knew he was not human. After the youth departed, he told his disciples: “That young man was a jiao-shen spirit. I fear that if we do not eliminate him, he will continue to bring floods to Jiangxi.” He surveyed the area with his Daoist vision and saw the spirit transformed into a yellow ox on a sandbar. Zhenjun said to his disciple Shi Taiyu: “That yellow ox is the one. I will transform into a black ox and engage it in battle with a white cloth. You must strike it with your sword.” Soon, the two oxen charged at each other, and Taiyu’s blade struck the yellow ox’s left thigh. It fled into a well west of the city, followed by the black ox, and the spirit escaped.

Earlier, the spirit had transformed into a clever young man in Tanzhou, amassing treasures and marrying the daughter of the prefect, Jia Yu. He often traveled the rivers and lakes, returning with abundant goods. This time, he returned empty-handed, claiming to have been robbed and wounded. Shortly after, the steward announced: “A Daoist named Xu Jingzhi seeks an audience with the prefect.” Jia Yu received him and seated him. Zhenjun said: “I hear you have a fine son-in-law. May I meet him?” Shen feigned illness and refused to appear. Zhenjun thundered: “Jiao spirit, old demon, how dare you conceal your form!” The spirit then reverted to its true shape before the hall, and Zhenjun commanded the celestial spirits to slay it. He also ordered the two children brought before him, sprinkled them with water, and they transformed into small shen. The wife, Jia Shi, nearly changed as well, but her parents pleaded fervently, and Zhenjun relented. He instructed them to dig over a *zhang* beneath the house, where the earth was dry and waterless. He then ordered them to move quickly. Moments later, the official residence sank entirely, leaving only the traces of the shen.

chunks.original_text: 后於东晋太康二年八月一日於洪洲西山举家白日上升，真君自飞升之后，里人与真君族人就其地立祠。 以所遗诗一百二十首写竹简之上，载之竹莆，令人探取以央休咎，名日圣签。 宋徽宗政和二年五月十七日上尊号曰：神功妙济真君。 改观为官，赐额日玉隆万寿。 帝因看书於崇政，恍然似梦见东华门北有一道士，戴九华冠披绛童服，导从者甚众，至丹墀起简揖帝。 帝因问曰：卿是何人，不诏而至。 对曰：吾为许旌阳，权掌九天司职，上帝韶往按察西瞿耶国，经由故国。
chunks.translated_text:
Later, in the second year of the Taikang era of the Eastern Jin dynasty, on the first day of the eighth month, the entire household ascended to the heavens in broad daylight at West Mountain in Hongzhou. After Zhenjun’s ascension, the villagers and his clansmen established a shrine on that site. They inscribed the one hundred twenty poems he had left behind onto bamboo slips, placed them in a bamboo basket, and allowed people to draw lots from them to divine fortune and misfortune—calling them the "Sacred Lots." On the seventeenth day of the fifth month in the second year of the Zhenghe era of Emperor Huizong of the Song, he was bestowed the honorific title: "Zhenjun of Divine Merit and Wondrous Salvation." The temple was elevated to an abbey, and the plaque was granted the name "Jade Prosperity and Longevity of Ten Thousand Years."

The emperor, while reading in the Chongzheng Hall, suddenly seemed to dream of a Daoist at the north of the Donghua Gate, wearing a Nine-Flowered Crown and a crimson robe, leading a great entourage. Approaching the vermilion steps, the Daoist bowed and presented a bamboo slip. The emperor asked: "Who are you, that you arrive without summons?" The Daoist replied: "I am Xu Jingyang, temporarily overseeing the affairs of the Nine Heavens. By the decree of the Supreme Emperor, I was passing through the former kingdom on my way to inspect the Western Kingdom of Shravasti."

chunks.original_text: 复问曰：朕患安息疮，诸药不能愈，真君有药否？ 即取小瓢子倾药一粒，如绿豆大，呵咒抹於疮上，觉如流酥灌体，入骨清冻。 遂揖而去，行数步随回顾曰：吾弊舍已久寥落，愿圣皇举眼一看为幸。 帝豁然而觉，韶画像如梦中所见，祥赐上清储祥宫崇奉，诏真君遗迩去处，未有宫观即取本属官职建造，如宫观只因损坏如法修换，无常住即拨近便官田供辨。 圣朝崇奉加至道玄应四字，余封如故。 张天师 天师者，汉张道陵也。 子房八世孙，光武建武问生於昊天目山，学长生之卫隐北郁山，章帝和帝累召不起，久之褊游名山。 东抵兴安云锦溪，升高而望曰：是有异境。 遂沂流而之云锦洞，有岩焉，炼丹其中。
chunks.translated_text:
The emperor further inquired: "I suffer from the *anxi* sores, and no medicine has been able to cure them. Does the Perfected Lord have a remedy?" The Perfected Lord immediately took a small gourd, poured out a single pill the size of a mung bean, breathed an incantation over it, and applied it to the sores. The emperor felt as though flowing ghee suffused his body, penetrating to the bone with a cool, soothing sensation. The Perfected Lord then bowed and departed. After several steps, he turned back and said: "My humble abode has long fallen into desolation. I would be most fortunate if Your Sacred Majesty would deign to glance upon it." The emperor awoke with a start, and at once ordered a portrait painted in likeness of the figure from his dream. It was enshrined with reverence in the Upper Clarity Repository of Auspicious Blessings Abbey. An edict was issued to seek out the Perfected Lord’s former dwelling; where no abbey or temple existed, officials of the local jurisdiction were to construct one. If any abbey or temple had fallen into disrepair, it was to be restored according to proper standards. Where no permanent endowment existed, nearby official fields were to be allocated for its upkeep. The sagely court honored him further with the four-character title "Mysteriously Responsive of the Supreme Dao," while his other honorifics remained unchanged.

**Celestial Master Zhang**
The Celestial Master was Zhang Daoling of the Han. A descendant of Zhang Liang in the eighth generation, he was born in the Wutianmu Mountains during the *Jianwu* era of Emperor Guangwu. He studied the arts of longevity and dwelled in seclusion on Mount Beiyu. Emperors Zhang and He repeatedly summoned him, but he declined. After a time, he wandered among the famous mountains. Traveling east to the Yunjin Stream in Xing’an, he ascended a height and gazed out, saying: "This place holds extraordinary wonders." He then followed the current to the Yunjin Grotto, where he found a cliffside cave and refined the elixir within.

chunks.original_text: 三年青龙白虎旋远於上，丹成饵之。 时年六十，容#6貌益少。 又得秘书，通神变化驱除妖鬼。 后於蜀之云台峰升天，所遗经录符章并印剑以授子孙。 其四代日盛，复居此山，历代重之。 今其子孙世袭真人居於江西广信府贵溪县之龙虎山。 三茅真君三月十八日生 茅盈字叔申，蒙玄孙。 弟固，字季伟。 次弟衷，字思和。 生於汉景帝中元五年，少秉异操独味清虚，年十八遂弃家入怛山修道饵木。 后师王君，因西至龟山得见王母，授以太极玄真之经，归入恒山北谷，时年四十九也。 盈父母尚存，父恶其久出远游欲杖之，盈长跪曰：盈已受圣师符录常有天兵侍卫，杖盈恐天兵相阻，盈罪愈加重也。 父欲验其语，故杖之，杖辄折成数十段。 如弓矢之发，中壁则壁穿，中柱则柱陷。 父母始知其道成，乃止。 盈曰：向所启正虑如此。 后二弟俱贵，衷为西河太守，固为执金吾。 当并之官，乡里送者数百人。 时盈亦在座，笑谓宾曰：吾虽不作二千石，来年四月三日送仆登仙，当亦不臧於今日也。 众皆不之许，时宣帝初元四年也。 至期门前数顷地，忽自平治无寸草，皆施青缣喔屋，下尽铺白毡，可容数百人。 众宾并集，大作宴会，杳无使从，但见金盘玉杯自至筵前，美酒奇般异果不可名状，复有妓乐丝竹金石之音满耳，兰麝之香达数里外。 少顷迎官来至，朱衣玉带者数百人，旌旗甲仗光采耀日。 盈乃与家人亲友辞别，登车乘云冉冉而去。 时二弟在官，闻盈飞升皆弃，还家求兄於东山。 盈乃与相见，谓二弟曰：悟何晚矣。 今年已俱老难可补复，纵得真诀但可成地仙耳。 於是初教二弟延年不死之法，令长斋三年，授以上道，使存明堂玄真之气，又各赠九转还丹一剂，并神方一首。 各佩服之，遂亦成仙。 后人谓之三茅真君，令祠庙鼎列於句容之茅山三峰，灵应奇验礼拜者价江以南云。 祠山张大帝 大帝姓张，讳渤，字伯奇。 武陵龙阳人也。 父龙阳君，母日张媪。 龙阳君与媪游於太湖之陂，忽风雨晦冥雷电并起失媪处，俄顷开霁，媪言见天神赐以金丹，已而有娠。 西汉神爵#7三年二月十一日夜半生，长而奇伟隆准修髯有神，告以地荒僻不足建家。 命行有兽前导，遂与李夫人东游昊会，渡浙江至曹云山白鹤山，山有四水会流其下，公止而居焉。 於白鹤得柳氏，於乌程桑址得赵氏为侍人。 王九弟五子一女八孙，始於昊与郡长兴县顺灵乡，役阴兵自长兴荆溪疏凿圣渍长三十里，志欲通津於广德也。 王□ 鼓坛为乌所误，王见夫人变形未及遂不与夫人相见，化於广德县西五里横山之顶，居民思之立庙祀焉。 夫人亦至县东二里而化，时人亦为立庙。 圣渍之河湮为民田，即浴兵池，为湖灌溉，濒湖之田仅万顷，挂鼓之坛，禽不敢柄，蚁不敢聚。 云唐大宝中梼雨感应，初赠水部员外郎，横山改为祠山。 昭宗赠司农少卿，赐金紫。 景宗封广德侯。 南唐封为司徒，封广德公。 后晋封为广德王。 宋仁宗封为灵济王。 至宁宗朝累加至八字王，至理宗淳佑五年改封正佑圣烈真君。 至感淳二年加封正佑圣烈昭德 昌福真君。 二月十一日诞生。 封正宁昭助灵惠顺圣妃。 李氏二月初二日诞生。 封协应济惠慈昭广懿夫人。 赵氏。 封协顺承济慈佑广助夫人。
chunks.translated_text:
After three years, the Azure Dragon and White Tiger circled above at a distance, and the elixir was completed. He consumed it, and though then sixty years of age, his appearance grew ever more youthful. He also obtained secret texts, mastering divine transformations to expel demons and spirits. Later, on Cloud Terrace Peak in Shu, he ascended to heaven, leaving behind his scriptures, talismans, seals, and sword to be passed down to his descendants. His lineage flourished through four generations, and they continued to dwell upon this mountain, revered through the ages. Today, his descendants, inheriting the title of Perfected One, reside at Dragon-Tiger Mountain in Guixi County, Guangxin Prefecture, Jiangxi.

**The Three Mao Perfected Lords**
The Three Mao Perfected Lords were born on the eighteenth day of the third month. Mao Ying, styled Shushen, was a descendant of Mao Xuan. His younger brothers were Mao Gu, styled Jiwei, and Mao Zhong, styled Sihe. Born in the fifth year of Emperor Jing of Han’s *Zhongyuan* era, Mao Ying was exceptional from youth, devoted to purity and emptiness. At eighteen, he left home to cultivate the Dao on Mount Da, consuming pine resin. Later, he studied under Master Wang, journeyed west to Tortoise Mountain, and was received by the Queen Mother of the West, who bestowed upon him the *Scripture of the Supreme Ultimate and Mysterious Perfection*. He returned to the northern valley of Mount Heng at the age of forty-nine.

Mao Ying’s parents were still living. His father, displeased with his prolonged absence, sought to cane him. Mao Ying knelt and said: "I have received sacred talismans from my master, and celestial soldiers always attend me. If you cane me, I fear they will intervene, and my offense will only grow heavier." His father, wishing to test his words, struck him, but the cane shattered into dozens of pieces, as if shot from a bow—where it struck the wall, the wall was pierced; where it struck a pillar, the pillar sank. Only then did his parents recognize his attainment of the Dao and desist. Mao Ying said: "I feared precisely this outcome."

Later, his two younger brothers both rose to prominence: Mao Zhong became Governor of Xihe, and Mao Gu became Commandant of the Palace Guard. When they were to depart for their posts, hundreds from their hometown came to see them off. Mao Ying, also present, smiled and said to the guests: "Though I do not hold a two-thousand-bushel office, next year on the third day of the fourth month, when I ascend as an immortal, the send-off will not be inferior to today’s." The crowd did not believe him. This was the fourth year of Emperor Xuan’s *Chuyuan* era.

On the appointed day, several *qing* of land before his gate suddenly leveled themselves, not a blade of grass remaining. They were covered with azure silk tents, and white felt carpets were laid beneath, accommodating hundreds. The guests assembled, and a grand feast was held. Though no attendants were seen, golden platters and jade cups appeared before the mats of their own accord, filled with fine wine, rare delicacies, and exotic fruits beyond description. Music of strings, bamboo, metal, and stone filled their ears, and the fragrance of orchid and musk wafted for miles. Soon, the welcoming officials arrived—hundreds clad in vermilion robes and jade belts, their banners and armor gleaming like the sun. Mao Ying bid farewell to his family and friends, then mounted his carriage and ascended upon the clouds, drifting away.

His two brothers, still in office, heard of Mao Ying’s ascension and resigned, returning home to seek their brother on the eastern mountain. Mao Ying appeared to them and said: "Why have you awakened so late? Now you are both aged, and though you may still attain the true methods, you can only become earthbound immortals." He first taught them methods to prolong life and avoid death, instructing them to maintain a strict fast for three years. He then transmitted the supreme Dao, teaching them to cultivate the *qi* of the Mysterious Perfection within the Hall of Light. To each, he gave a dose of nine-times-cycled returning elixir and a divine formula. They ingested and wore these, and thus also attained immortality. Later generations called them the Three Mao Perfected Lords. Their temples stand in majestic array upon the three peaks of Mount Mao in Jurong, where their numinous efficacy is wondrously manifest. Pilgrims from south of the Yangtze flock to pay homage.

**Lord Zhang of Mount Ci**
The Great Emperor’s surname was Zhang, his given name Bo, and his courtesy name Boqi. He was a native of Longyang in Wuling. His father was the Dragon Lord of Longyang, and his mother was Lady Zhang. The Dragon Lord and Lady Zhang were traveling by the embankments of Lake Tai when suddenly a storm arose—wind, rain, and darkness, with thunder and lightning. Lady Zhang vanished, but after a moment, the skies cleared, and she said she had seen a celestial deity who bestowed upon her a golden elixir. Soon after, she conceived.

On the night of the eleventh day of the second month in the third year of the *Shenjue* era of the Western Han, he was born. As he grew, he became extraordinarily tall, with a prominent nose, long whiskers, and an awe-inspiring presence. He declared that the land was too desolate to establish a home. Following an animal that guided his path, he journeyed east with Lady Li to Wu and Kuaiji, crossed the Zhe River, and arrived at Mount Caoyun and White Crane Mountain. There, four streams converged below the mountain, and the lord settled there.

At White Crane Mountain, he took Lady Liu as his consort, and at Mulberry Site in Wucheng, he took Lady Zhao as his attendant. He had nine younger brothers, five sons, one daughter, and eight grandsons. Initially, in Wu and Changxing County of Guiji Prefecture, he employed yin soldiers to dredge and excavate the Sacred Ditch, extending thirty *li* from Changxing to Jingxi, intending to connect the waterway to Guangde. The lord’s drum platform was misled by a crow, and seeing that Lady Li had transformed, he did not meet with her again. He transformed atop Mount Heng, five *li* west of Guangde County, and the locals, missing him, established a temple in his honor. Lady Li also transformed two *li* east of the county, and the people built a temple for her as well.

The river of the Sacred Ditch silted up and became farmland, now known as the Bathing Soldiers’ Pond. It formed a lake for irrigation, nourishing nearly ten thousand *qing* of fields along its shores. The Drum Platform remains—birds dare not perch there, nor ants gather. It is said that during the *Dabao* era of the Tang, prayers for rain were answered. He was first posthumously appointed Gentleman of the Waterworks. Mount Heng was renamed Mount Ci. Emperor Zhaozong of the Tang posthumously appointed him Vice Minister of Agriculture and bestowed upon him the title of *Jinzi*. Emperor Jingzong of the Later Tang enfeoffed him as Marquis of Guangde. The Southern Tang enfeoffed him as Minister of Works and Duke of Guangde. The Later Jin enfeoffed him as King of Guangde. Emperor Renzong of the Song enfeoffed him as King of Lingji. By the reign of Emperor Ningzong, his title had expanded to an eight-character honorific. In the fifth year of *Chunyou* during the reign of Emperor Lizong, he was renamed Perfected Lord of Upright Protection, Sacred Efficacy, and Illustrious Might. In the second year of *Duanping*, he was further honored as Perfected Lord of Upright Protection, Sacred Efficacy, Illustrious Virtue, Prosperity, and Blessed Fortune.

His birthday, the eleventh day of the second month, was celebrated. Lady Li, born on the second day of the second month, was enfeoffed as Consort of Harmonious Response, Beneficent Aid, Compassionate Radiance, and Vast Kindness. Lady Zhao was enfeoffed as Consort of Harmonious Compliance, Bearing Aid, Compassionate Protection, and Vast Assistance.

Emperors Zhang and He repeatedly summoned him, but he declined. After a time, he wandered among the famous mountains. Traveling east to the Yunjin Stream in Xing’an, he ascended a height and gazed out, saying: "This place holds extraordinary wonders." chunks.original_text: 淑显柔嘉令仪夫人。 王婿李夫人本广无像位醮筵及祠祭呼云。 王孙 第一位永福侯。 第二位衍社侯。 第三位衍佑侯。 第四位衍泽侯。 第五位衍瑞侯。 第六位衍渥侯。 第七位衍庆侯。 第八位衍惠侯。 佐神丁壬三圣者，打供方使者，封协灵住。 五圣始末九月二＋八生 按《祖殿灵应集》云：五显公之神在天地问相与为本始，至唐光启中乃降於兹邑，图籍莫有登载，故后来者无所考据。 惟邑耆耄口以相传，言邑民王瑜有园在城北偏，一夕园中红光烛天，邑人麋王观之，见神五人自天而下，道从威仪如王侯状，黄衣皂丝坐胡床，呼瑜而言曰：吾授天命当食此方，福佑斯人，什胜寻幽而来至止，我庙食此则佑汝亦无穷。 瑜拜首曰：惟命。 言讫，祥云四合，神升天矣。 明日邑人来相宅，方山在其东，佩山在其西，左环杳墩，右绕蛇城，南壮两潭，而前坐后大溪，北来萦纡，西下两峰，特秀巉然，水口良然，佳处也。 乃相与子来斩竹萝草作为华屋，立像肖貌揭虔安灵，四远闻之鳞集辐辏。 自是神降，格有功於国，福佑斯民，无时不显。 先是庙号止名五通，大中中始赐庙额日灵顺，宣和年问封两字侯，绍兴中加四字侯，乾道中加八字侯，淳熙初封两字公，甲辰问封四字公，十一年加六字公，庆元六年加八字公，喜泰二年封两字王，喜定元年封四字王，累有阴助于江左，封六字王，六年十一月诰下封八字王，理宗改封八字王号： 打供胡百二检察。 都打供胡靖一总管。

The royal son-in-law, the Lady Li, originally held the position of *Guangwu Wuxiang* and presided over the ritual altar and sacrificial rites, where she was invoked as follows:

The royal grandsons:
First: Marquis of Eternal Blessings.
Second: Marquis of Extending the Community.
Third: Marquis of Extending Protection.

Fifth: Marquis of Extending Auspiciousness.

Seventh: Marquis of Extending Felicitation.

The assisting deities, the Three Sages of *Ding* and *Ren*, and the ritual attendants were enfeoffed as *Xieling Zhu*.

The Five Sages’ origins: born on the twenty-eighth day of the ninth month.
According to the *Record of the Ancestral Hall’s Divine Responses*: The deities of the Five Manifest Lords existed between Heaven and Earth as their primordial origin. During the *Guangqi* era of the Tang, they descended upon this town. No records were kept in official registers, so later generations had no means to verify their history. Only the town’s elders transmitted the account orally: A townsman, Wang Yu, owned a garden on the northern outskirts. One night, a crimson glow illuminated the sky above the garden. The townspeople, led by Mi Wang, observed five deities descending from Heaven, their retinue and bearing like those of kings and marquises. Clad in yellow robes with black silk sashes, they sat upon armrest chairs and summoned Yu, saying: “We are entrusted with Heaven’s mandate to receive offerings in this land and bestow blessings upon its people. Tenfold greater than seeking seclusion, we have come to dwell here. If our temple is established here, your blessings shall be boundless.” Yu bowed and replied, “As you command.” With these words, auspicious clouds gathered on all sides, and the deities ascended to Heaven.

The next day, the townspeople came to inspect the site. To the east stood Fang Mountain, to the west Pei Mountain. On the left, Yaodun Hill encircled it; on the right, Shecheng coiled around it. To the south, two ponds stood majestic, while a great stream flowed before and behind. From the north, the terrain wound sinuously; from the west, two peaks descended, uniquely precipitous and verdant. The water’s outlet was propitious—a fine location indeed. Together, they cut bamboo and thatched grass to construct a splendid hall, sculpted images in the deities’ likeness, and reverently enshrined their spirits. Word spread, and people from afar gathered in throngs.

Since then, the deities descended, demonstrating merit for the state and bestowing blessings upon the people without cease. Initially, the temple was simply called the *Five Manifestations*. During the *Dazhong* era, it was granted the temple plaque *Lingshun*. In the *Xuanhe* era, the deities were enfeoffed as Two-Character Marquises. In the *Shaoxing* era, they were elevated to Four-Character Marquises; in the *Qiandao* era, to Eight-Character Marquises. In the early *Chunxi* era, they were enfeoffed as Two-Character Dukes; in the *Jiachen* year, as Four-Character Dukes. In the eleventh year, they were elevated to Six-Character Dukes; in the sixth year of *Qingyuan*, to Eight-Character Dukes. In the second year of *Jiatai*, they were enfeoffed as Two-Character Kings; in the first year of *Jiding*, as Four-Character Kings. For their unseen assistance in the Jiangzuo region, they were enfeoffed as Six-Character Kings. In the sixth year, an imperial edict in the eleventh month elevated them to Eight-Character Kings. Emperor Lizong later altered their title to the Eight-Character Kingly designation.

chunks.original_text: 打供黄太保。 打供王太保。 金吾二大使。 掌善罚恶判官。 《周礼小宗伯》祀五帝於四郊，汉仪祠五祀，宋朝明堂图五方帝位於昊天之侧，从之以五人帝，五官神皆五行直气也。 盖五行为天地闲至大，化叉有为之主宰者，故日玄冥，日祝融，日勾芒，曰神专，曰后土，皆指水火金木土而言之。 则今五神之降於此，岂非默助五行之造化，以福生民乎。 或以五圣为五通，谓其非正神，名实不辨甚矣。 每岁四月八日本县启建大斋，士民辐奏。 本朝有褒封勅诰： 第一位显聪昭应灵格广济王，显庆协惠昭助夫人。 第二位显明昭列灵护广佑王，显惠协庆善助夫人。 第三位显正昭顺灵卫广惠王，显齐协佑正助夫人。 第四位显直昭佑灵既广泽王，显佑协齐喜助夫人。 第五位显德昭利灵助广成王，显福协爱静助夫人。 王祖父启佑喜应敷泽侯，祖母衍庆助顺慈既夫人。 王父广惠慈济方义侯，母崇福慈齐庆善夫人。 长妹喜应赞惠淑显夫人，次妹懿顺福淑靖显夫人。 至有吏下二神者，盖五公，既贵不欲以祸福惊动人之耳目，而委是二神司之欤。 黄衣道士，紫衣员觉大帅。 辅灵斓善史侯，辅顺斓惠下侯。 斓应助顺周侯，令狐寺丞。 王念二元师，打供高太保。 至圣炳灵王五月十二日生 至圣炳灵王者，即东岳天齐仁圣帝第三子也。 唐太宗加威雄将军，至宋太宗封上昊炳灵公，大中祥符元年一月十五日封至圣炳灵王。 佑圣真君 佑圣真君者，真．君姓茅，讳盈，本长安咸阳人也。 自幼出家，参访名山洞府，遇王君赐长生之术，得道称为天仙。 至汉明帝朝仪朔三年，天书忽降，皆玉篆龙文，云大帝保命真君与东岳天齐仁圣帝同鉴死生共管阴府之事。 宋太宗封佑圣真君，至真宗加封九天司命上卿赐福佑圣真君。 王侍宸 侍宸姓王，名文卿，宋时临川人。 侍宸，其官也。 主有骨相，有道者器之。 长而游四方，履历几遍宇宙，尝遇异人授以道法，能召风雷。 宋徽宗号为金门羽客凝神殿侍宸，宠冠当时，赐责一无所受。 时扬州大旱，诏求雨，侍宸为父剑噗水曰：借黄河水三尺。 后数日扬州奏得雨水皆黄浊。 屡见显异。 元时始建祠，今祠在建昌之府城内是也。 灵应益者，执牲帛而乞灵者络绎於道。 袁千里 袁胜，字千里，南丰人，王侍宸甥生氏子也。 有斩勘雷法髻髭舅氏，端平问寓戴颠家，一日谓戴颠曰：吾逝矣，可焚我。 言毕而卒，戴焚之及及尸烟焰中有旗，现金字曰：雷云第二判官袁千里也。 张果老 姓张，名果，隐於恒州中条山，往来汾晋。

The *Dagong* Huang Taibao.
The *Dagong* Wang Taibao.
The Two Commanders of the Gold Mace.
The Judges Who Reward Good and Punish Evil.

According to the *Rites of Zhou: Minor Zongbo*, the Five Thearchs were sacrificed to in the four suburbs. The Han ceremonial system worshipped the Five Sacrifices. In the Song dynasty’s *Mingtang* diagram, the Five Directional Thearchs were positioned beside the August Heaven, accompanied by the Five Human Emperors and the Five Official Spirits—all manifestations of the qi governing the Five Phases. For the Five Phases are the greatest forces between Heaven and Earth, the sovereigns of all transformation and action. Thus, they are named Xuanming, Zhurong, Goumang, Rushou, and Houtu—each corresponding to Water, Fire, Metal, Wood, and Earth. If these Five Spirits descend here, is it not to silently aid the creative transformations of the Five Phases and bless the people?

Some mistakenly equate the Five Sages with the *Wutong* spirits, claiming they are not orthodox deities—a confusion of names and reality indeed. Every year on the eighth day of the fourth month, this county holds a grand fast, drawing crowds of scholars and commoners.

The imperial edicts of our dynasty have conferred the following titles:

**First Rank:**
Manifestly Wise, Resonantly Responsive, Numinously Efficacious, Vastly Beneficent King;
Manifestly Auspicious, Harmoniously Blessed, Resonantly Assisting Consort.

**Second Rank:**
Manifestly Illustrious, Resonantly Arrayed, Numinously Protective, Vastly Blessing King;
Manifestly Benevolent, Harmoniously Auspicious, Kindly Assisting Consort.

**Third Rank:**
Manifestly Upright, Resonantly Compliant, Numinously Guarding, Vastly Kind King;
Manifestly Harmonious, Harmoniously Assisting, Uprightly Aiding Consort.

**Fourth Rank:**
Manifestly Upright, Resonantly Blessing, Numinously Nourishing, Vastly Merciful King;
Manifestly Assisting, Harmoniously Harmonious, Joyfully Aiding Consort.

**Fifth Rank:**
Manifestly Virtuous, Resonantly Beneficent, Numinously Aiding, Vastly Accomplished King;
Manifestly Fortunate, Harmoniously Loving, Tranquilly Assisting Consort.

**Ancestral Line:**
The King’s paternal grandfather: Initiating Protection, Joyfully Responsive, Spreading Mercy Marquis;
His grandmother: Prolonging Blessings, Assisting Compliance, Compassionately Nourishing Consort.

The King’s father: Vastly Kind, Compassionately Beneficent, Squarely Righteous Marquis;
His mother: Honoring Blessings, Compassionately Harmonious, Auspiciously Kind Consort.

His elder sister: Joyfully Responsive, Assisting Wisdom, Gracefully Manifest Consort;
His younger sister: Reverently Compliant, Fortunate and Kind, Tranquilly Manifest Consort.

As for the two subordinate spirits, it is said that the Five Lords, being exalted, do not wish to startle the eyes and ears of the people with matters of fortune and misfortune, and thus delegate these tasks to the two spirits.

The Yellow-Robed Daoist;
The Purple-Robed Yuanjue Great Marshal.

The Assisting Numinous, Brilliant and Kindly Scribe Marquis;
The Assisting Compliant, Brilliant and Benevolent Subordinate Marquis.

The Brilliant and Responsive, Assisting and Compliant Zhou Marquis;
Magistrate Linghu.

The Two Yuan Masters, Wang Nian;
The *Dagong* Gao Taibao.

**The Most Sacred, Illuminously Numinous King** (born on the twelfth day of the fifth month):
The Most Sacred, Illuminously Numinous King is the third son of the Eastern Peak, Heavenly Equal, Benevolent and Sacred Thearch. Emperor Taizong of Tang bestowed upon him the title of Mighty and Heroic General. By the time of Emperor Taizong of Song, he was enfeoffed as the Supreme August, Illuminously Numinous Duke. In the first year of *Dazhong Xiangfu*, on the fifteenth day of the first month, he was elevated to the Most Sacred, Illuminously Numinous King.

**The Protective Sage Perfected Lord:**
The Protective Sage Perfected Lord, surnamed Mao and named Ying, was originally from Xianyang in Chang’an. From childhood, he left home to seek the Dao, visiting famous mountains and grottoes. He encountered the Perfected Lord Wang, who bestowed upon him the arts of longevity, and he attained the Way, becoming known as a Heavenly Immortal. During the reign of Emperor Ming of Han, in the third year of *Yongping*, a celestial script suddenly descended, inscribed in jade seal characters with dragon patterns, proclaiming that the Great Thearch, Protective Life Perfected Lord, would jointly oversee matters of life and death in the netherworld with the Eastern Peak, Heavenly Equal, Benevolent and Sacred Thearch. Emperor Taizong of Song enfeoffed him as the Protective Sage Perfected Lord, and Emperor Zhenzong later elevated him to the Nine Heavens’ Controller of Destinies, Supreme Minister, Bestowing Blessings Protective Sage Perfected Lord.

**Wang Shichen:**
Shichen, surnamed Wang and named Wenqing, was a native of Linchuan during the Song dynasty. *Shichen* was his official title. He possessed an extraordinary physiognomy, and those of the Dao esteemed him. In his youth, he traveled the four directions, traversing nearly the entire cosmos. He once encountered an extraordinary person who transmitted to him the Daoist arts, enabling him to summon wind and thunder. Emperor Huizong of Song honored him as the Golden Gate Feathered Guest and *Ningshen* Hall *Shichen*, his favor unmatched at the time, though he declined all rewards. When a great drought struck Yangzhou, an imperial edict sought rain. Shichen drew his sword and struck the water, saying, “I borrow three feet of the Yellow River’s water.” Several days later, Yangzhou reported rain, its waters yellow and turbid. He repeatedly displayed numinous wonders. During the Yuan dynasty, a shrine was first established for him, and today it stands within the prefectural city of Jianchang.

Those who hold sacrificial animals and silk to seek numinous responses crowd the roads.

**Yuan Qianli:**
Yuan Sheng, styled Qianli, was a native of Nanfeng and the nephew of Wang Shichen. He mastered the arts of commanding thunder and lightning, inheriting them from his uncle. During the *Duanping* era, he lodged with Dai Dian. One day, he said to Dai Dian, “I am departing. You may cremate me.” Having spoken, he passed away. Dai cremated him, and amidst the flames of the pyre, a banner appeared, inscribed in golden characters: *Yunlei Er Pandao Yuan Qianli* (Second Judge of Thunderclouds, Yuan Qianli).

**Zhang Guolao:**
Surnamed Zhang, named Guo, he secluded himself on Mount Zhongtiao in Hengzhou, traveling between Fen and Jin.

chunks.original_text: 闻得长生秘术，耆老云：为儿童时见之，已言数百岁。 尝骑一白驴日行数万里，休息时乃折迭之，其厚如纸，置於巾箱中。 乘则以水异之，复成一驴。 唐太宗高宗征之不出，则天皇后召之出山，佯死於拓女庙前。 后有人於恒州山中复见之，明皇宝玺书迎里随至，安置於集贤院。 问以神仙，不答，累试仙术不可穷纪。 西岳真人 西岳真人姓冯，名长，骊山人。 周宣王时为柱下史，睹天文之变乃退隐摄生，遇邓真人授以灵书，功行垂成，复遇彭真人授以太上隐书，遂得仙用术活人。 平王二十年春升化而去。 太素真人九月二十三日生 太素真人姓周，名亮，字太真，太原人。 母宵寝见五色流霞覆其宅因感有孕，经十五月而生。 长而师事姚坦授《五千文》及#8《八素真经》，能治鬼怪，各复真形。 周灵王太子晋闻之，召与相见，赐以九光七明芝。 亮修服之，遂能变化，或如七十发白齿落经宿不出，复为少年姿容如花，或被凶人侮之，其人不觉自缚，困於拷击叫号口中流血，求哀乃释之。 年一百九十余岁，威烈王十四年上帝遣天官下迎，授为秦陇真人，出入太清。 萨真人 萨真人名守坚，蜀西河人也。 尝学医，误用药杀人，遂弃医。 闻虚靖张天师，及建昌王侍宸、福州林灵素三人道法高，遂来学法。 至蜀中，其行囊已尽，坐於石大忧。 忽见三道人来，真人问此去信州远近，道人问所欲。 真人曰：欲访虚靖天师学法。 道人曰：天师死矣。 复问王侍宸，曰亦死矣。 复问林灵素，曰亦死矣。 真人方怅恨，一道人曰：今天师道法亦高，吾与之有旧，当为作字，可往访之。 吾有一法相授，日问可以自给。 遂授以吮枣之术，日呎一枣可取七文，一日但呎十枣得七十文，则有一日之资矣。 一道人曰：吾亦有一法相授，与之棕扇一柄，曰有病者则扇之即愈。 一道人曰：吾亦有一法相授，乃雷法也。 真人受之，辞去。 用之皆验。
chunks.translated_text:
He was said to have mastered the secret arts of longevity. Elders recalled seeing him in their youth, already claiming to be several centuries old. He once rode a white donkey that could travel tens of thousands of *li* in a day. When resting, he would fold it up until it was as thin as paper and store it in his headscarf box. To ride again, he would sprinkle water upon it, and it would transform back into a donkey. Emperor Taizong and Emperor Gaozong of the Tang summoned him, but he refused to emerge. Empress Wu Zetian later called him out of the mountains, yet he feigned death before the Temple of Tuo Nu. Later, someone encountered him again in the mountains of Hengzhou. Emperor Xuanzong sent an imperial edict to welcome him, and he arrived shortly after, being installed in the Academy of Scholarly Worthies. When questioned about the immortals, he remained silent, though his divine arts were tested repeatedly without end.

**Perfected of the Western Marchmount**
The Perfected of the Western Marchmount, surnamed Feng and named Chang, was a native of Mount Li. During the reign of King Xuan of Zhou, he served as *zhuxiashi* (archivist). Witnessing celestial omens, he retired to cultivate longevity. He encountered Perfected Deng, who transmitted to him sacred scriptures. As his merit and practice neared completion, he met Perfected Peng, who bestowed upon him the *Hidden Writ of the Supreme*. Thereupon, he attained transcendence and used his arts to save lives. In the twentieth year of King Ping’s reign, he ascended and departed.

**Perfected of Great Simplicity**
The Perfected of Great Simplicity, surnamed Zhou and named Liang, styled Taizhen, was a native of Taiyuan. His mother, while resting one night, saw five-colored radiant clouds covering her home and conceived. After fifteen months, she gave birth. In his youth, he studied under Yao Tan, who transmitted to him the *Five Thousand Character Writ* and the *Eightfold Scripture of True Simplicity*. He could subdue malevolent spirits, restoring them to their true forms. Crown Prince Jin of King Ling of Zhou heard of him and summoned him for an audience, bestowing upon him the *Ninefold Radiance and Sevenfold Brilliance Mushroom*. Liang ingested it and gained the power of transformation: at times, he would appear as a seventy-year-old with white hair and fallen teeth, yet after a night’s seclusion, he would reemerge as a youth with a visage like blossoms. If ever insulted by ruffians, the offenders would unknowingly bind themselves, suffering blows and cries until their mouths bled, only to be released upon begging for mercy. At over one hundred ninety years of age, in the fourteenth year of King Weilie’s reign, the Celestial Emperor dispatched heavenly officials to welcome him, appointing him Perfected of Qin and Long and granting him entry into the Great Purity.

**Perfected Sa**
Perfected Sa, named Shoujian, was a native of Xihe in Shu. He once studied medicine but, having mistakenly killed a patient with his prescriptions, abandoned the profession. Hearing of the lofty arts of Celestial Master Zhang Xujing, Wang Shichen of Jianchang, and Lin Lingsu of Fuzhou, he traveled to study under them. Arriving in Shu, his provisions were exhausted, and he sat upon a rock, deeply troubled. Suddenly, three Daoist adepts appeared. The Perfected asked how far it was to Xinzhou. The adepts inquired about his purpose. He replied, “I wish to seek Celestial Master Xujing to study the Dao.” The adepts said, “The Celestial Master has passed away.” He then asked about Wang Shichen, and they replied, “He too has passed.” He asked about Lin Lingsu, and they said, “He also has died.” The Perfected grew despondent, whereupon one adept said, “Though the Celestial Master is gone, his arts remain profound. I am acquainted with him and shall write a letter on your behalf. You may go to seek him. I will also teach you a method to sustain yourself daily.” He then transmitted the art of sucking jujubes: each jujube sucked would yield seven *wen*, and by sucking ten a day, he could earn seventy *wen*—enough for a day’s livelihood. Another adept said, “I too have a method to teach you,” and gave him a palm-leaf fan, saying, “Wave this over the sick, and they will recover.” The third adept said, “I also have a method to teach you,” and transmitted the arts of thunder. The Perfected received these teachings and departed. All proved efficacious when put into practice.

chunks.original_text: 一日凡呎百余枣，止授七十文为日用，余者复以济贫。 及至信州见天师，投书，举家皆哭，乃虚靖天师亲笔也。 书中言，吾与王侍宸、林天师遇萨君，各以一法授之矣。 可为参录奏名真人，后法愈大显。 尝经潭州，人闻神语曰：真人提刑来日至。 次日，人同之，只见真人携瓮笠至，有提点刑狱之牌，人异之。 继至湘阴县浮梁，见人用童男童女生祀本处庙神，真人曰：此等淫神，好焚其庙。 言讫雷火飞空，庙立焚矣。 真人至龙兴府江边濯足，见水有神影，方面黄巾金甲，左手拽袖右手执鞭，真人曰：尔何神也？ 答曰：吾乃湘阴庙神王善，被真人焚吾庙后今相随一十二载，只候有过则复前佛。 今真人功行已高，职隶天枢，望保奏以为部将。 真人曰：汝凶恶之神，坐吾法中必损吾法。 庙神即立誓不敢背盟，真人遂奏帝授职。 至漳州，忽一日诸将现形环侍，天诏召真人君天枢领位，真人方起身而即立化。 寿春真人 真人姓梅，名福，字子真，寿春人。 仕汉为南昌尉，见王莽专政乃弃家求仙。 遍游疡荡南闽诸山，后入仙霞山，遇空同仙君授以内外丹法。
chunks.translated_text:
One day, he sucked over a hundred jujubes but accepted only seventy *wen* for daily expenses, using the remainder to relieve the poor.

Upon arriving in Xinzhou to meet the Celestial Master and presenting the letter, the entire household wept, for it was in the hand of the Vacuously Tranquil Celestial Master. The letter stated, “I have encountered Adept Sa along with Attendant Wang Shen and Celestial Master Lin, each of whom transmitted a method to him. He may be recorded as a Perfected One for memorial submission; later, his arts will grow ever more illustrious.”

Once, passing through Tanzhou, people heard a divine voice proclaim, “The Perfected One, Commissioner of Penal Affairs, arrives tomorrow.” The next day, the people gathered and saw only the Perfected One approaching with a bamboo hat and jar, bearing a placard inscribed *Commissioner of Penal Affairs*—they marveled at the sight.

Proceeding to the Floating Bridge in Xiangyin County, he saw locals sacrificing boys and girls to the local temple deity. The Perfected One said, “Such licentious spirits deserve to have their temple burned.” As soon as he spoke, thunder and fire descended from the sky, and the temple was instantly consumed.

When the Perfected One reached the riverbank in Longxing Prefecture to wash his feet, he saw the reflection of a deity in the water—square-faced, wearing a yellow kerchief and golden armor, his left hand grasping his sleeve and his right hand holding a whip. The Perfected One asked, “What spirit are you?” The reply came, “I am Wang Shan, the deity of the Xiangyin temple. After you burned my temple, I have followed you for twelve years, awaiting an opportunity to avenge myself. Now that your merit and conduct are lofty and your office is under the Celestial Pivot, I beseech you to memorialize and appoint me as a subordinate general.” The Perfected One said, “You are a malevolent spirit; if I seat you within my arts, you will surely harm them.” The temple deity immediately swore an oath never to betray the covenant, whereupon the Perfected One memorialized the Emperor and conferred upon him an official post.

Arriving in Zhangzhou, one day all the generals manifested their forms and surrounded him in attendance. A celestial edict summoned the Perfected One to assume the position of Lord of the Celestial Pivot. The Perfected One then rose and immediately transformed.

**Perfected One of Shouchun**
The Perfected One’s surname was Mei, given name Fu, courtesy name Zizhen, a native of Shouchun. He served the Han as Magistrate of Nanchang but, seeing Wang Mang usurp power, abandoned his family to seek immortality. He wandered through the mountains of southern Min and Fujian, later entering Xianxia Mountain, where he encountered the Immortal Lord of Kongtong, who transmitted to him the arts of inner and outer elixirs.

chunks.original_text: 入鸡笼山修炼不成，乃至剑江西岭。 再遇空同仙君。 谓福曰：汝之绿在飞鸿山也。 福遂往飞鸿山结庵修炼，丹成趣装复还寿春。 一日，紫云浮空仙乐纷纷，金童玉女捧诏控鸾从空而下，福拜诏辞家乘青鸾飞升而去。 宋元丰问，封寿春真人。 今庙在金陵聚宝门外，灵应神异，俗呼曰梅将军庙。 负局先生 负局先生，语似燕代问人，因磨镜辄问主人得无有疾苦者否，若有辄出紫丸赤药与之，莫不愈。 时大疫，每列户与药愈者万计，不取一钱。 后止昊山绝崖，世世悬药与人。 曰：吾欲还蓬莱山为汝曹下神水，崖头一旦有水白色从石崖流‘下，服者多所愈。 乡人乃立祠杞之。 律吕神
chunks.translated_text:
Entering Jilong Mountain, his cultivation remained unfulfilled, so he proceeded to the western ridge of the Jian River. There he again encountered the Immortal Lord of Kongtong, who addressed Fu: "Your destiny lies upon Feihong Mountain." Fu then journeyed to Feihong Mountain, where he built a thatched hut to refine his elixir. Once the cinnabar was complete, he hastened to pack and returned to Shouchun. One day, purple clouds drifted across the sky amid swirling immortal music, and golden lads and jade maidens descended bearing an edict, riding phoenixes from the heavens. Fu received the edict, bid farewell to his family, and ascended on a blue phoenix. During the Yuanfeng era of the Song, he was enfeoffed as the Perfected One of Shouchun. His temple now stands outside Jubao Gate in Jinling, renowned for its divine efficacy and marvels, commonly called the Temple of General Mei.

**Master of the Alchemy Satchel**
The Master of the Alchemy Satchel spoke with an accent reminiscent of the Yan and Dai regions. Whenever he polished mirrors, he would ask the owner if they suffered any ailments; if so, he would produce purple pills and red medicines for them, and all were cured. During a great epidemic, he distributed medicine to households, healing tens of thousands without accepting a single coin. Later, he dwelled upon the sheer cliffs of Mount Wu, where he perpetually dispensed medicine to people. He declared, "I wish to return to Penglai Mountain to bring down divine water for you all." One day, milky water flowed from the stone cliff, and many who drank it were healed. The villagers then erected a shrine to worship him.

The shrine stands five *li* north of Hunyuan Prefecture in Datong Prefecture, atop Fox Stone by the Divine Stream, first constructed during the Northern Wei and later restored under the Yuan. According to legend, in the sixth month of the first year of the Tai Chu era, a man from Hongzhou named Zhang Gui rested at dusk upon Fox Stone when suddenly a divine figure—elegant, radiant, and untouched by worldly dust—descended from the heavens. Gazing at Gui, the spirit intoned, *"Lülü, lülü, Heaven commands you: on the twentieth day of this month, a violent storm shall strike."* With these words, the figure ascended into the sky. Gui grasped the warning and returned home to urge his neighbors to hasten the wheat harvest. Those who failed to gather their crops by the appointed day saw them ruined by the deluge. The matter reached the imperial court, and envoys were dispatched to offer sacrifices.

Master Liu, compiler of *A Comprehensive Record of the Universe*, bore the surname Liu and the courtesy name Mohe. Profoundly versed in the scriptures and precepts, he delved deeply into the essence of meditation, and his divinations of fortune and misfortune never failed to prove true. During the reign of Juqu Mengxun, he sought immortality and studied the Dao, eventually settling in a small thatched hut south of Suzhou’s garrison. There, he joined his palms in reverence, took refuge in the Three Jewels, and entered *nirvana*. His disciples cremated his remains, whereupon his bones transformed into pearls and his blood into cinnabar. A shrine was erected at the site of his passing. It is said that those who pray there often receive pearls and elixirs. Since then, supplicants have found that fires are extinguished when invoked, rains pour forth when beseeched, and illnesses are cured when entreated—so much so that devotees from near and far vie to honor him.

**Records of Divine Marvels, Third Scroll #1**

**Catalogue**
Guanyin (Avalokiteśvara)　　　　Heavenly Kings　　　　Kṣitigarbha (Earth Treasury)
Vajra Warriors　　　　　Ten Great Wisdom Kings　　Ten Lords of the Ten Courts of Hell
